importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Retail coffee prices increased nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the same month in 2024, highlighting the economic impact of tariffs on consumer prices.
The Trump administration imposed significant tariffs on coffee imports in July 2025, with Brazil facing a 50% duty, Vietnam a 20%, and Colombia a 10%, directly contributing to supply cost increases.
Rep. Don Bacon and Rep. Ro Khanna introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs, signaling political efforts to mitigate the economic burden.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from July to October 2025 is central to the article, as it captures the immediate economic effects of new tariffs on coffee import costs and pricing dynamics.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil (30.7%), Colombia (18.3%), and Vietnam (6.6%) being the primary suppliers according to UN Comtrade data.
Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration — particularly a 50% duty on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia — have significantly increased the cost of imported coffee beans.
Retail coffee prices rose by nearly 21% in August 2025, with an average restaurant coffee price reaching $3.52, up 10 cents from the previous year.
In Washington, DC, a regular hot coffee averaged $4.21 in August (up 4%), and cold brew averaged $5.35 (up 3.7%), reflecting localized consumer price impacts.

Coffee roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting report increased costs due to tariffs, with some shifting sourcing strategies to diversify supply chains.
Consumers may adjust brand choices or reduce quality expectations to save money, but coffee is perceived as an affordable luxury, and consumption habits are unlikely to shift dramatically.
Small businesses face heightened uncertainty and financial pressure due to tariff-induced cost volatility, with owners stating that pricing unpredictability threatens long-term viability.
A bipartisan legislative proposal — the 'No Coffee Tax Act' — was introduced in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs, showing political recognition of the economic strain on the industry.

namedEntities.name: Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former U.S. President, associated with the imposition of tariffs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s administration imposed significant tariffs on coffee imports, which directly increased costs for U.S. roasters and consumers.

namedEntities.name: Brazil
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Country, primary coffee exporter to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brazil is the largest supplier of U.S. coffee (30.7% of imports) and faced a 50% tariff, making it the most heavily impacted country in the tariff policy.

namedEntities.name: Vietnam
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Country, significant coffee exporter to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vietnam supplies 6.6% of U.S. coffee imports and faced a 20% tariff under the Trump administration's policy.

namedEntities.name: Colombia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Country, significant coffee exporter to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Colombia supplies 18.3% of U.S. coffee imports and faced a 10% tariff under the Trump administration's policy.

namedEntities.name: Swing’s Coffee Roasters
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Coffee roastery based in Virginia and Washington, DC, founded in 1916
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This roastery directly experienced higher costs due to tariffs and environmental factors, and its owner cited consumer cost burdens as a primary concern.

namedEntities.name: Vigilante Coffee Company
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Coffee roastery with locations in California and Maryland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This business reports a 50-cent increase in price per 12-ounce bag of beans and has considered shifting sourcing to diversify and maintain affordability.

namedEntities.name: Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Coffee roastery based in Silver Spring, Maryland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The owner avoided Brazilian coffee due to 50% tariffs and noted a 63-cent increase in bean costs per pound since January 2025.

namedEntities.name: Qualia Coffee
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Coffee business selling at farmers’ markets in DC
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Owner Joel Finkelstein highlighted the uncertainty and financial strain on small businesses due to unpredictable pricing from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Don Bacon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Ro Khanna
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Co-introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Toast
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided data showing a 21% year-over-year increase in coffee prices and price trends in restaurants and cities like Washington, DC.

namedEntities.name: National Coffee Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. organization representing the coffee industry
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cited that the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, providing context on the country’s reliance on international supply chains.

namedEntities.name: UN Comtrade Database
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided data on U.S. coffee import origins, such as Brazil, Colombia, and Vietnam, used to establish supply chain dependencies.

namedEntities.name: Conference Board
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided economic analysis from senior economist Erin McLaughlin, who noted consumer behavior shifts in response to price increases.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration's imposition of steep tariffs — including a 50% duty on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia — has significantly raised the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to a 21% year-over-year increase in retail coffee prices. As the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil being the largest supplier, roasters such as Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting are facing rising costs, with consumers ultimately bearing the financial burden. Despite efforts by some businesses to diversify sourcing and political proposals like the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' to exempt coffee from tariffs, consumers are adapting through brand switching or reduced quality expectations. However, coffee remains perceived as an affordable luxury, and consumption habits are not expected to shift dramatically, even with price increases.
title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Brewing Trouble for Coffee Roasters
